1974-2002
NYHS-RG 28Collection processed by Margaret KaczorowskiThis record group was processed as part of the 2015-2016 N-YHS Institutional Archives project, made possible by a generous grant from the Leon Levy Foundation.New-York Historical SocietyNew-York Historical Society170 Central Park WestNew York, NY 10024(212) 873-3400This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2022-08-06T01:19:17EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard
The documents in the collection are in English.
New-York Historical Society
New-York Historical Society audiovisual media records
New-York Historical Society
NYHS-RG 28
12.13 Linear feet in nine record cartons and eight document boxes.
1974-2002 The New-York Historical Society audiovisual media records primarily include videocassettes and audiocassettes from the late 1980s to early 1990s. N-YHS's lectures, panel discussions and concerts organized around the "Why History?" theme (1990-92) and programs connected to the bicentennial of the U.S. Constitution (1987) are especially well-documented, though many other presentations in video or audio format are also included. Audiotapes include training for docents and N-YHS education staff concerning particular N-YHS exhibitions and gallery installations. The record group is currently restricted because of the lack of appropriate playback equipment and the fragility of the tapes. The record group is restricted. The record group includes audiovisual formats that are too fragile to play. Access requires special arrangements/reformatting of the media. The materials are stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
Arrangement Note
The record group is organized in three series:
Series I. Moving Images
Series II. Audiotapes
Series III. Digital Media
Accruals Note
Further accruals to the record group are expected over time.
Scope and Contents Note
The record group includes audiovisual formats, primarily videocassettes and audiocassettes, that were found in the archive as standalone objects. (Audiovisual formats found in exhibition or other files remain in those files in other record groups.) These formats date principally from the late 1980s to early 1990s, though there are some into the early 2000s. The subject matter of the videotapes includes mostly public programs, especially the "Why History?" lectures and panel discussions of 1990-1992. Educational programs, public service announcements, exhibition openings, and some History Makers award events have videos. Audiotapes also include programs, such as "Why History?," but also have a broader range of topics, including docent and education staff training for exhibitions and gallery installations. Programs related to the exhibition Government by Choice: Inventing the U.S. Constitution and other initiatives connected to the bicentennial of the Constitution in 1987 are well-represented in the record group. The record group is currently restricted because of the lack of appropriate playback equipment and the fragility of the tapes.
Preferred Citation Note
This record group should be cited as New-York Historical Society audiovisual media records (NYHS-RG 28), The New-York Historical Society.
Processing Information Note
Most of the material in the record group was compiled and boxed at some point, likely in the early 2000s. In December 2016, project archivist Margaret Kaczorowski processed additional material into the record group, inventoried all the content at the item level, and described the whole in this finding aid. None of the media were played during processing; all of the description of the subject matter is based on information from the labels on the media.
Related Archival Materials Note
This finding aid relates to just one record group of the New-York Historical Society archives. For information about the other record groups and for overall information about the archives, please see the Guide to the New-York Historical Society Archives (NYHS-RG Archives). Other record groups that are processed and available to researchers and are especially related to the New-York Historical Society audiovisual media records (NYHS-RG 28) are as follows:
Much of the record group relates to public and education programs and docent training with respect to exhibition and gallery tours. Documentation about these programs can be found in the New-York Historical Society public programs and education records (NYHS-RG 23).
This record group includes only those audiovisual and digital formats found as standalone objects when the archive was processed in 2015-16. Media found in files with other documents, such as exhibition files, were left with those records. Tapes are rare in these other files, but digital formats such as CDs and DVDs are common, especially in the New-York Historical Society Museum Department records (NYHS-RG 20).
Access Restrictions
The record group is restricted. The record group includes audiovisual formats that are too fragile to play. Access requires special arrangements/reformatting of the media. The materials are stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.

United States Constitution Bicentennial, 1987-1991 New York (N.Y.) -- History -- Societies, etc. United States -- History -- Study and teaching. New-York Historical Society. Public Programs Department New-York Historical Society -- Archives. New-York Historical Society. Education Department
Series I. Moving Images8.3 Linear feet1985-2002
Arrangement Note
The container list includes an inventory of items in sequential box order. The items appear to have been fitted into boxes in no particular order and the inventory reflects that.
The subject descriptions and dates used in the container list were taken from the labels on the item. [Bracketed] descriptions were added by the processing archivist. The formats (e.g., VHS, Betacam) noted in the container list were determined by the archivist's observations; where the archivist was uncertain of the format, the description "format?" was used.
Scope and Contents Note
The series includes moving image formats, primarily videocassettes in VHS, Betacam, and U-Matic formats. The bulk of these date from the late 1980s and early 1990s and, judging only from the labels, the subject matter primarily concerns programs held at N-YHS. Most extensively documented in these tapes are the lectures, panel discussions and some concerts presented as part of the "Why History?" series that ran from 1990-92. These series linked various programs to particular themes, including "Race and Class" in 1991 and "What is American?" in 1992. Educational initiatives are also documented here, including high school student mock Constitutional Convention debates, the Liberty Scholars partnership with Bank Street College, and the Lab School collaboration with I.S. 44.
The moving images also include public service announcements (PSAs), interviews, and exhibition openings. Many of these relate to N-YHS's exhibition Government by Choice: Inventing the U.S. Constitution and other tie-ins to the bicentennial of the Constitution in 1987. Tapes of special events are also included, such as some of the History Makers Award ceremonies (including the second one, in 1989, honoring Malcolm Forbes) and former President Bill Clinton's July 2001 appearance.National Portrait Gallery "Faces of Colonial America" (VHS)1988 August 81-WWOR-TV The Joe Franklin Show with Arthur Marks from the N-YHS (U-matic?)undated1-Reminisce #1-6 (2 tapes) (VHS)undated1-Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Company. Scope and Contents Note
Includes a VHS videocassette of the Gotbaum interview that aired in Japan, and a companion booklet to the video with an English transcription under the title, "Making Historical Objects Accessible and Exciting." The booklet also includes a transcription of an interview with N-YHS Curator of Architectural Collections Mary Beth Betts on the topic of "Photographs as History."Three PSA's from the N-YHS "Government By Choice" Exhibition (open reel, tape)1987 September 317-
Scope and Contents Note
Includes PSAs for Program 1: George Clinton and Program 2: Thomas Jefferson.Series II. Audiotapes3.46 Linear feet1974-1991
Arrangement Note
The container list includes an inventory of items in sequential box order. The items appear to have been fitted into boxes in no particular order and the inventory reflects that.
The subject descriptions and dates used in the container list were taken from the labels on the item. [Bracketed] descriptions were added by the processing archivist.
Scope and Contents Note
The series includes audiocassette tapes (and a few open reels and a tape cartridge) dating primarily from the late 1980s and early 1990s. Judging only from the labels, the subject matter appears to primarily include public lectures and presentations held at N-YHS and training/background sessions, likely for docents, educators and other N-YHS staff responsible for conveying exhibition interpretative comments to the public. Many of the tapes include the lectures, panel discussions and some concerts presented as part of the "Why History?" series that ran from 1990-92. Other tapes include lectures by guest speakers and N-YHS curators that related to exhibitions, including those by N-YHS museum curator Annette Blaugrund on Paris 1889 (1989) and The Taste of Andrew Carnegie (1991), N-YHS Librarian James Mooney on Putting New York on the Map (1988), and Professor Mosette Broderick on McKim, Mead & White's New York (1991), to name just a few. Tapes related to docent training include, among many others, museum curator Ella Foshay on the Niagara (1986) and Hudson River School (1987) exhibitions, curator Tim Burgard on Thomas Cole's The Course of Empire (1989), and N-YHS educators Carole Slatkin and Jane Lattes on Audubon (1987) and firefighting (1985) exhibitions, respectively. Some tapes provide collection overviews, including an "Introduction to Department of Public Programs: Highlights for Teachers" (1986) and Ella Foshay on "Treasures of the New-York Historical Society" (1988). Many tapes related to programs connected to the bicentennial of the Constitution are found in the series, including guest curator Betsy McCaughey on the exhibition Government by Choice: Inventing the U.S. Constitution (1987) and the series of educational programs broadcast on radio.Early American Leaders Training Session (Debby Longman)1985 September 129-Ethnic Festivals for Children undated9-

Scope and Contents Note
Tape reel # U-683. Interview of Heslin by WNYC/93.9 FM/TV/31. Aired January 1975.Government by Choice PSAs (open reel, tape)1987 September 14162
Scope and Contents Note
Label for 7 1/2 ips ft mono reads :30 & :60 PSA's for N-YHS's "Government By Choice."N-YHS Adult/Child Narrative (4 open reels, tape)1987 March 1017-
Scope and Contents Note
This is likely the introduction to N-YHS and its collections produced in 1986-87. Consists of four open reels with the identifying number S-7761 on each. There are three 15 feet reels labeled Outs (Dolby), Pulsed Mixes (Endless Loop), and Adult/Child Slide Narration. One reel is labeled Mix 7 Voice 5. 3 reels appear to be audio; the fourth is uncertain and might be the slides to accompany the narrative.The Great Experiment / Constitution Slide Show (3 open reels, tape)1987 September 1117-
Scope and Contents Note
Consists of three open reels with the identifying number T-9912 on each. The reels are labeled N-YHS Constitution 'Outs', "Constitution" Narrative Pulsed, and the third is labeled "The Great Experiment" and contains a typed script with annotations. The first two reels are audio; the third is uncertain but might be the slide show.Series III. Digital Media0.36 Linear feetcirca 1980s-2002
Arrangement Note
The items are in no particular arrangement.
Scope and Contents Note
The series includes a small number of digital formats. The most useful is the 2002 DVD concerning a tribute to N-YHS honorees Colin and Nancy Campbell. The bulk of the series includes 5-1/4 inch floppy disks, many of which appear to be operating system or other software applications for personal computers.In Trust to America: A Tribute to Colin and Nancy Campbell2002152
Scope and Contents Note
Produced by the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, this 9 minute DVD film celebrates the awarding of the N-YHS's DeWitt Clinton Medal to the Campbells. DVD features Society President Kenneth T. Jackson and was screened at the History Makers Gala in 2002.The Making of Alice in Wonderland[2009]153
Scope and Contents Note
Disk contains the numbers 2009.39 and 2009.40, possible Museum object numbers.Backup Multi Lotus Inventory (8 floppy disks)undated154
Scope and Contents Note
Consists of 5-1/4 inch disks. Disks appear to be software programs and are individually labeled Formatted DSK 31-34, Backup System Backup, PC Tools Backup, and DOS 3.2.Software Etc. (10 floppy disks)circa 1980s?15-
Scope and Contents Note
Consists of 5-1/4 inch disks. Several disks are labeled as Invoices, D-Base, Whi and Mo Bkup.The remainder are unlabeled.Documents (9 floppy disks)Before Fiscal Year 1993161
Scope and Contents Note
Consists of 5 1/4 inch disks. Disks are individually labled as: N-YHS Emergency Plan Draft, Labels/Exhibition, Technical Services Job Description, Correspondence, and Budget Table.
